Robert wrote:

> You're the one who keeps referring to the creation of new classes as
> creating public classes, Elliotte.

We may be talking past each other then. I don't object to new 
package-private classes and methods as part of refactoring, or in 
initial design. But we do need to be really clear about distinguishing 
between public and package-private. I don't think you've always been as 
clear as you think. For instance, here's a quote from the first message 
I found from you still in my Inbox:

	Wanting to test them is a symptom, to me, of a violation of the SRP.
	 Exposing private methods as public, on an appropriate class, helps
	me to avoid SRP-violations, and helps promote reuse to reduce
	duplication.

	The other driver I have to make private methods public is explicitly
	to reduce duplication. For example, maybe it's you doing the
	String-to-Calendar trick in another class. You know where you did it
	before, so you extract it out and reuse it. However, this only works
	because you're familar with what you did earlier - it didn't work
	for Jane because she wasn't.

That talks about public. Now if by "public" you only meant non-private, 
then we don't really disagree; but can you see why I may have thought we 
did? This is a real flaw in Java. I really, really wish there were a 
standard word for package-private/package-protected/default 
access/whatever.
